questions.text: A patient in ICU is started on a blood transfusion. Within 20 minutes, the patient develops fever with chills and flank pain. His urine appears red in color. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has a sudden onset of fever with chills, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria soon after starting blood transfusion. The most likely diagnosis is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction. 

It occurs due to the preformed IgM antibodies against the donor red cells. These antibodies cause complement-mediated lysis of red blood cells. The patient will present with fever, abdominal, flank, or back pain, hemoglobinuria, and hypotension.

When it is suspected, the transfusion should be immediately stopped, and the blood bank should be notified about the reaction. The blood bank should evaluate the patient's blood samples for hemolysis and the presence of antibodies. Antibodies can be tested for by direct antiglobulin test (DAT), sometimes called the direct Coombs test. The blood levels of lactate dehydrogenase, indirect bilirubin, and serum haptoglobin should be assessed. 

Non-immunologic reactions:

  1. Fluid overload
  2. Hypothermia
  3. Hypocalcemia due to increased chelation of calcium by citrate
  4. Hyperkalemia due to increased release of potassium from lysed cells
  5. Iron overload
  6. Transient hypotension
  7. Transfusion-mediated immunomodulation- Multiple sittings of transfusion of allogenic blood leads to immunosuppression.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a COPD patient in ICU developing palpitations and the ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with more than three different P wave morphologies, points to the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image) with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness. The clinical features are most commonly related to the underlying precipitating illness (COPD in this case). Unlike atrial fibrillation, there are clear isoelectric intervals between P waves.

Treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities is the mainstay of treatment. Electrical cardioversion has no effect.

The calcium-channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem may slow the atrial and ventricular rate. MAT may respond to amiodarone, but long-term therapy with this agent is usually avoided due to its toxicities, particularly in pulmonary fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A man who sustained a crush injury during an earthquake was rescued. His blood pressure was stable and no internal bleeding was detected. A significant reduction in his urine output was noted after some time. Investigations showed urine/plasma creatinine ratio < 20 and urinary sodium of 50 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI). The history of crush injury is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis leading to AKI.

AKI is defined as a decline in kidney function within 7 days, resulting in the accumulation of nitrogenous waste and other toxic metabolites usually excreted in the urine. It includes a variety of conditions that share some common features such as elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output. It is broadly divided into three categories:

  • Prerenal azotemia 
  • Intrinsic parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction

Intrinsic causes can further be divided into acute tubular necrosis, acute glomerulonephritis, and acute interstitial nephritis. Ischemia and nephrotoxins are the main causes of acute tubular necrosis. Nephrotoxins can be exogeneous such as vancomycin, cisplatin, and iodinated contrast agents used for CT imaging. Endogenous toxins include myoglobin, uric acid, and hemoglobin. Crush injuries, heat stroke, and myopathies can result in rhabdomyolysis releasing large amounts of myoglobin. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is usually ≤ 40.

In acute tubular necrosis, urinary sodium is >20 mEq/L. 

Prerenal azotemia arises due to a reduced renal plasma flow. Common causes include hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is ≥ 40 and urinary sodium is usually <20mEq/L.

Bladder outlet obstruction, urethral obstruction, and benign prostatic hyperplasia lead to postrenal azotemia. Urinary sodium can be variable.

More causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man consults a doctor because he is feeling increasingly tired and has lost around 10 kgs in the last 6 months. Physical examination revealed pallor and splenomegaly. Complete blood count of the patient revealed Hb-10mg/dL, WBC counts- 1,50,000/ cu.mm and platelet count of 500000 per microliter of blood. Peripheral smear shows the following. The patient was timely diagnosed and was started with appropriate treatment. Which of the following will be helpful in assessing the prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows increased WBCs with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms. A basophil can also be seen. This implies that the patient has chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Sokal scoring is used in assessing the prognosis of this patient.

Majority of the patients with CML present with easy fatigability, anorexia, abdominal discomfort, early satiety (related to splenic enlargement), weight loss, and excessive sweating. 

Blood investigations may show anemia, leucocytosis, and thrombocytosis. It has decreased or absent levels of neutrophil alkaline phosphatase activity. 

Peripheral smear of CML will show an increased number of white blood cells with myeloblasts, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms. Basophils can also be increased.

The prognosis of CML can be assessed by

  • Sokal score- It is based on
    • Age
    • Spleen size
    • Platelet count
    • Percentage of blast cells in the blood
  • Hasford score- It uses Sokal variables along with the percentage of eosinophils and basophils in the blood. 

Other options

Option A- Rai and Binet staging system is used for staging chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

Option B- Ann Arbor staging system is used in Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas.

Option D- Lugano staging system is used for staging lymphomas.

Related Pearl: Ann Arbor Staging for Hodgkin and NonHodgkin Lymphoma

Stage Distribution of disease
I

Involvement of a single lymph node region (I)

or 

a single extra lymphatic organ or site (IE)
II

Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm alone (II)

or

localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site (IIE)
III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm without (III) or with (IIIE) localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site
IV

Diffuse involvement of one or more extra lymphatic organs or sites with or without lymphatic involvement 

All stages are further divided on the basis of the absence (A) or presence (B) of fever, night sweats and/or unexplained weight loss >10% of body weight.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about fibromuscular dysplasia?

choices.text: String of beads appearance on angiography
Most commonly affected peripheral artery is subclavian artery

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the string of beads appearance on CT angiography is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common peripheral (limb) arteries affected are the iliac arteries.

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a segmental, non-atheromatous, dysplastic type of angiopathy that predominantly affects females. The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia. It is one of the major causes of renovascular hypertension. The most common sites of involvement in decreasing order of frequency are as follows:

  1. Renal arteries
  2. Carotid arteries
  3. Peripheral (limb) arteries - most commonly iliac arteries

On angiography, a string of beads appearance is seen as shown below.

questions.text: An elderly man who is a known case of hypertension and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with decreased urine output and facial puffiness. His estimated glomerular filtration rate was 20 mL/min/1.73 sq. m. According to the KDIGO classification, what is the stage of his chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
According to the KDIGO classification, the stage of this patient's chronic kidney disease (CKD) is G4.

CKD is a spectrum of pathophysiological processes resulting in abnormal kidney function, with a progressive decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). According to the Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcome (KDIGO) classification, CKD can be stratified using both GFR and albuminuria to predict the risk of progression of CKD:

Stages of CKD based on GFR (mL/min/1.73 sq.m):

Stage GFR  Description
G1 ≥90 Normal or high
G2 60-89 Mildly decreased
G3a 45-59

Mildly to moderately decreased
G3b 30-44 Moderately to severely decreased
G4 15-29 Severely decreased
G5 <15 Kidney failure

Stages of CKD based on albuminuria (mg/g):

Stage Albuminuria Description
A1 <30 Normal to mildly increased
A2 30-300 Moderately increased
A3 >300 Severely increased

questions.text: A middle-aged man, who smokes around 8-9 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years presented with chronic cough and breathlessness. Initially, breathlessness was mild, but now it has gradually affected his day-to-day activities. A pulmonary function test showed FEV1/FVC to be 0.65 and FEV1 is 75% of the predicted value. What is the severity of the disease?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical vignette, the patient is a chronic smoker and has chronic progressive breathlessness, along with chronic cough. The diagnosis is likely to be chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. According to Gold's criteria, the severity of the disease in this patient is moderate.

The severity of COPD is assessed by using the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) criteria. In pulmonary function testing, a postbronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio of <0.70 is considered diagnostic for COPD. 

The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) system categorizes COPD into following stages,

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

In patients with FEV1/FVC <0.7

GOLD I

Mild

FEV1 ≥80% predicted

GOLD II

Moderate

FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

GOLD III

Severe

FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

GOLD IV

Very severe

FEV1 <30% predicted

Note: FEV1/FVC is measured after the administration of a bronchodilator.

questions.text:
A young woman was brought to the emergency department after she had an episode of syncope. Her heart rate was 50 beats per minute. ECG was taken immediately and is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?

AV - atrioventricular
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of syncope with bradycardia are suggestive of a Stokes-Adams attack. ECG findings of the atrioventricular block with RBBB suggest the diagnosis of Mobitz type II block.

In the given ECG, the PR segment remains the same in each successive cycle. However, some P waves are not followed by QRS complexes, which means that some of the P waves are blocked. This is typical of Mobitz type II block. The other finding present is a right bundle branch block that is seen as a wide QRS and rsR' pattern in V1 - V3.

Stokes Adam's attack refers to the syncopal attack resulting from bradycardia or asystole.

Atrioventricular (AV) blocks can be of three types based on ECG appearance:

  • First-degree AV block occurs due to the slowing of conduction within the AV node. 
    • The ECG will show a fixed prolongation of PR interval that is more than 200ms.
  • Second-degree AV block occurs due to the intermittent failure of impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. They can be of two types:
    • Mobitz type I/Wenckebach block is seen as a progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by an absence of one QRS complex (non-conducted P wave).
    • Mobitz type II block occurs due to an infranodal pathology. Here the PR intervals are fixed, but, there are intermittent non-conducted P waves. 
  • Third-degree AV block/complete heart block (CHB) occurs when none of the impulses from the atria is conducted to the ventricles.
    • The ECG shows complete AV dissociation, which means that there is no relation between the P waves and QRS complexes.

AV node block can occur due to myocardial infarction, fibrosis, sclerosis, and cardiac infiltrative diseases. Iatrogenic causes include cardiac valvular surgery and drugs like digoxin, beta-blockers, verapamil, and diltiazem. 

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

Related Pearl: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG 

If the bradyarrhythmia is persisent causing hemodynamic instability, then the management is as depicted by the flowchart (based on the AHA guidelines) below:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was referred to a haematologist following symptoms of easy bruising and recurrent epistaxis.  Further workup revealed JAK-2 mutations. Identify the true statement regarding this condition:

choices.text: Hemoglobin level of >16 g/dL in women is diagnostic
Associated with lower risk of thrombotic events
High levels of serum erythropoietin is seen

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with JAK2 mutations on workup, is indicative of polycythemia vera (PV). The true statement regarding this condition is that a haemoglobin level of >16 g/dL in women is diagnostic.

PV is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets accumulate in the absence of a recognisable physiologic stimulus.

It is common among women before the fifth decade of life, and the most common cytogenetic abnormality in PV is the JAK2 mutation. 

Clinical features of polycythemia vera include easy bruising, epistaxis, acid-peptic disease, or gastrointestinal haemorrhage due to vascular stasis or thrombocytosis. Systolic hypertension and neurologic symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances, and transient ischemic attacks (TIA) occur due to erythrocytosis.

In some patients, venous or arterial thrombosis involving cerebral, cardiac, or mesenteric vessels may be seen. Intra-abdominal venous thrombosis is particularly common in young women and maybe catastrophic if a sudden and complete obstruction of the hepatic vein occurs.

Patients also complain of aquagenic pruritus, where they have generalised itching following a warm bath or a shower. On examination, there is splenomegaly and lab reports reveal elevated haemoglobin, hematocrit, and red blood cell counts.

Diagnostic criteria for PV: 

  • Major criteria - 
    • Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men and >16 g/dL in women or hematocrit of >49% in men and 48% in women
    • Bone marrow biopsy - hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis), including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation
    • Presence of JAK-2 mutation
  • Minor criterion - subnormal erythropoietin levels

A diagnosis of PV requires all three major criteria or the first two major and one minor criterion.

questions.text:
A young woman complains of burning sensation during micturition, increased urinary frequency, and urgency. She does not complain of fever, flank pain, or colicky abdominal pain. Which of the following is/are the first-line medications used in this condition?
  1. Nitrofurantoin
  2. Ampicillin
  3. Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole
  4. Ciprofloxacin
  5. Cephalosporins
questions.solution:
The given clinical sceanrio is suggestive of uncomplicated urinary tract infection (UTI), and nitrofurantoin and trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole are the first-line drugs used in this condition.

UTI encompasses many clinical entities, including asymptomatic bacteriuria, cystitis, prostatitis, and pyelonephritis. When the infection is confined to the bladder, also known as acute cystitis (the most common manifestation), it is known as uncomplicated UTI. This is more prevalent among women than men. When the infection extends beyond the bladder, causing systemic symptoms and signs, it is known as complicated UTI.

Frequent sexual intercourse, a history of UTI, diabetes, and incontinence are some of the important risk factors of UTI. It is most commonly caused by E. coli. Other species include Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterococcus, and Citrobacter species. 

Patients with cystitis typically present with dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. Nocturia, hesitancy, suprapubic discomfort, and gross hematuria can also be seen. Fever with a typical high spiking picket-fence pattern and rigors, flank and/or loin pain, nausea, and vomiting are seen in pyelonephritis. UTI can be complicated by the presence of infection, stones or foreign bodies, or delayed response to treatment.

Treatment in a patient with uncomplicated cystitis is started based on history alone. However, if symptoms are not specific or history is not reliable, a urine dipstick test is performed. Emperical treatment can be started in a woman with one symptom of UTI and a positive nitrite or leukocyte esterase result. In case of a negative result, urine culture and pelvic examination are recommended.

Antibiotic therapy include:

  • Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SFX) and nitrofurantoin: These are the first-line drugs for uncomplicated cystitis. However, TMP-SFX show high rates of resistance and adversely affect the normal flora in the body. Pivmecillinam, fosfomycin, and nitrofurantoin can be used instead. 
  • Beta-lactam antibiotics: These are the second-line agents due to high rates of relapse and lower pathogen clearance.
  • Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin): These are used for uncomplicated cystitis only if no other alternatives are available due to high rates of resistance and side effects like increased risk of Achilles tendon rupture and irreversible neuropathy. However, they are the first-line drugs for pyelonephritis.
  • Ampicillin and cephalosporins: These are drugs of choice in pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors of UTI

Risk Factors for Urinary Tract Infection

Demographic factors

  • Female Gender
  • Male infants (UTI is Males>females during infancy alone)

Structural factors - Any anatomical hindrance to drainage

  • Vesicoureteral reflux (for pyelonephritis)
  • Neuropathic Bladder
  • Pregnancy
  • Constipation
  • Obstructive uropathy
  • Uncircumcised male

Practices & Procedures:

  • Toilet training
  • Voiding dysfunction
  • Wiping from back to front in Females (not males)
  • Tight clothing (underwear)
  • Urethral instrumentation

Infective Factors

  • Pinworm infestation
  • Infection of Bacteria with P fimbriae

questions.text: A 45-year-old overweight man who is being treated for hypertension presents to you with complaints of snoring and episodic gasping during sleep. He also gives a history of fatigue, morning headaches, and daytime somnolence. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Overnight polysomnography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome which is described here.

Obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome is a debilitating condition seen commonly among males of older age, with a sedentary lifestyle. Other risk factors include obesity, family history, mandibular deformities, and hypothyroidism. It is also associated with hypertension and diabetes. Usually, there is a decline in neuromuscular output to pharyngeal dilator muscles during sleep. In predisposed individuals, this results in complete (apnea) or partial (hypopnea) pharyngeal collapse.

They present with symptoms such as snoring, gasping, and snorting during sleep. Other features include daytime sleepiness, morning headaches, and fatigue. Five or more episodes of apnea/ hypopnea per hour of sleep determined by a sleep study such as an overnight polysomnogram is a requirement for diagnosis. Such sleep studies, usually measure breathing, oxygenation, the position of the body, and cardiac rhythm. 

A polysomnogram helps to quantify sleep latency, sleep efficiency, and the time spent in each sleep stage. A negative test rules out obstructive sleep apnea. Management includes lifestyle modifications, treatment of exacerbating comorbidities, and continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).

Syndrome Z is used to describe the interaction between obstructive sleep apnea and the components of metabolic syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Electroencephalography is a study used to assess the electrical activity of the brain. It is used in the diagnosis and management of seizure disorders. It is also a component of sleep studies. 

Option B: Chin electromyography can be used to assess sleep cycle and continuity. 

Option D: Actigraphy used a device known as an actigraph worn on the wrist as a rough measure of the sleep-wake cycle. It can be used to assess insomnia, movement disorders, and circadian rhythm disorders. 

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Causes of Secondary Hypertension

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. A chest radiograph reveals a moderate pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis is performed and results are given below. What is the most likely cause of pleural effusion in this patient?
  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio: 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio: 0.6
  • Pleural fluid glucose: 65 mg/dL
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pleural effusion in the setting of acute breathlessness and chest pain that meets the criteria for exudative pleural effusion, along with pleural fluid glucose levels above 60 mg/dL. is likely to be due to pulmonary embolism.

The effusion in pulmonary embolism is a result of increased pulmonary capillary permeability leading to interstitial fluid moving from the lung to the pleural space by crossing the visceral pleura. The increased permeability is caused by the release of inflammatory mediators from clots that are rich in platelets. 

Transudative and exudative pleural effusions are distinguished by measuring the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein levels in the pleural fluid. Exudative pleural effusions meet at least one of the following criteria, whereas transudative pleural effusions meet none:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum

Also if the difference between the protein levels in the serum and the pleural fluid is >3.1 g/dL, it is likely to be transudative pleural effusion.

If the fluid appears to be exudate, then pleural fluid glucose levels can help in identifying the etiology. If the glucose levels are less than 60 mg/dL, then the effusion is likely due to malignancy, parapneumonic effusion (bacterial infection), and rheumatoid pleuritis.

Examples of transudative pleural effusions are effusions due to congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, and nephrosis. Exudative pleural effusions are caused by malignancies, bacterial infections, rheumatoid pleuritis, and pulmonary embolism.

If the pleural fluid cytology, culture, glucose, and staining do not yield any result, perform spiral CT to rule out pulmonary embolism and assess the markers of tuberculosis.

Other options:

Option A and C : Congestive heart failure and cirrhosis are examples of transudative pleural effusion.

Option B: Although this patient's exudative effusion may be parapneumonic, the absence of fever, sudden onset of symptoms, chest x-ray without consolidation, and normal pleural fluid glucose make bacterial infection a less likely cause.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text:
Match the JVP tracings with the conditions seen.

a. Tricuspid stenosis

b. Tricuspid regurgitation

c. Atrial fibrillation

d. Cardiac tamponade

e. Atrioventricular block
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-e, 2-b, 3-d, 4- c.

Image 1 shows canon a waves which are seen in atrioventricular (AV) block and right atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve.

 

Image 2 shows accentuation of v wave and rapid y descent which is seen in tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Image 3 shows absent y descent which is seen in cardiac tamponade.

 

Image 4 shows an absence of a waves which is seen in atrial fibrillation.

 

The below image shows a prolonged y descent seen in tricuspid stenosis.

 

The below image shows rapid 'x' and 'y' descent as seen in constrictive pericarditis.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text:
A 35-year-old  patient presents to the emergency department with a history of acute breathlessness. On examination, he is hypotensive, the heart sounds are muffled, JVP is increased, with
a prominent "x"  descent but an absent "y" descent.  Which of the following will be the most likely finding seen on the ECG of this patient?

choices.text: Low ECG voltage and electrical alternans
Raised ST segment with upward concavity

questions.solution:
A 35-year-old  patient with acute breathlessness, falling BP, rising JVP (with a prominent "x" descent but an absent "y" descent), and soft heart sounds suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. In a cardiac tamponade, the ECG findings are low voltage and electrical alternans.

Cardiac tamponade:

Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space raises the intrapericardial pressure, hence poor ventricular filling and fall in cardiac output.

It is characterized by:

  • Hypotension
  • Pulsus paradoxus
  • Increased pulse rate
  • Prominent X descent
  • Muffled heart sound
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at left angle of scapula)
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, Raised JVP, Small quiet heart or soft heart sound.

Investigation:

  • X-ray chest - Big globular heart
  • ECG - Low voltage, Electrical alternans
  • ECHO - Echo free zone around the heart
  • Cath - Diastolic collapse of right atrium and right ventricle

Treatment: Drainage of fluid

Other options:

The diastolic dip-and-plateau pattern, also known as a square root sign, is produced when early rapid diastolic inflow into the ventricle commences but is then abruptly halted by an opposing force. It is seen in constrictive pericarditis.

In constrictive pericarditis : Right atrial pressure is elevated with a prominent “y” descent, indicating rapid filling of the right ventricle during early diastole. 

ECG showing pericardial effusion with tamponade; arrows indicate electrical alternans:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was rushed to the ER with chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. On examination, her respiratory rate was 32/min, and carpopedal spasm was noted while measuring BP. Her ECG was normal. Which of the following acid-base disorders is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic attack. The patient is likely to have respiratory alkalosis. 

Panic attacks are characterized by hyperventilation which leads to a washout of CO2 (reduced PaCO2). This further increases the ratio of bicarbonate concentration to PaCO2 and, thereby, increases the pH level causing alkalosis. 

Alkalosis promotes the binding of calcium to albumin and reduces the fraction of ionized calcium in the blood. This leads to hypocalcemia without reducing the total calcium levels. Thus, alkalosis can precipitate tetany and laryngospasm, especially in calcium-deficient patients. 

Induction of carpopedal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more is called Trousseau sign. It is a clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia. 

Causes of respiratory alkalosis:

  • Central nervous system stimulation:
    • Pain
    • Anxiety, psychosis
    • Fever
    • Cerebrovascular accident
    • meningitis, encephalitis
    • Tumor
    • Trauma
  • Hypoxemia or tissue hypoxia:
    • High altitude
    • Pneumonia, pulmonary edema
    • Aspiration
    • Severe anemia
  • Drugs or hormones:
    • Pregnancy
    • Salicylates
    • Cardiac failure
  • Stimulation of chest receptors:
    • Hemothorax
    • Flail chest
    • Cardiac failure
    • Pulmonary embolism
  • Miscellaneous:
    • Septicemia
    • Hepatic failure
    • Mechanical hyperventilation
    • Heat exposure
    • Recovery from metabolic acidosis

Note: While metabolic alkalosis can also cause hypocalcemia, the above scenario of hyperventilation is more suggestive of respiratory alkalosis. Furthermore, hypocalcemic symptoms are more common with respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old Japanese woman was brought to the emergency department with worsening angina and palpitations. Her physical examination was normal. ECG showed giant T wave inversions and coronary angiography was normal. Left ventriculography showed spade-like deformity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of giant T wave inversions and spade-like deformity on left ventriculography points to a diagnosis of apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is also called Yamaguchi syndrome. It is characterized by hypertrophy of the myocardium, predominantly in the left ventricular apex. It was first described in the Japanese population and is uncommon in other populations.

The symptoms are milder and the risk of sudden cardiac death is lower than in the traditional septal form of HCM. 

The image below shows the ace of spades appearance on left ventriculography:

 

The image below shows the ace of spades appearance on echocardiography with massive hypertrophy of the apex and relative sparing of the base:

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient with COVID-19 who was on invasive ventilation was given 40 mg of methylprednisolone for 7 days. After recovery, he developed facial pain and swelling. The tissue obtained from the sinuses showed the following finding.  If amphotericin B is not available, which other drug can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing ribbon-like, irregular, aseptate hyphae is suggestive of mucormycosis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the first line of treatment. If Amphotericin B is not available, isavuconazole can be given to this patient.

Mucormycosis is a group of highly invasive, progressive, even life-threatening infections caused by fungi of the order Mucorales. Important fungi are rhizopus, mucor, actinomucor, etc.

These mucorales are present almost everywhere in the environment and humans are constantly exposed. But, infection is usually seen in immunocompromised states such as diabetes mellitus, glucocorticoid treatment, solid organ or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and prolonged neutropenia. Recently, there was a rise in incidence of mucormycosis (which was alredy hyper-endemic in india) during the Covid 19 pandemic. 

It can presentin five forms: Rhino-orbital-cerebral, pulmonary, cutaneous, gastrointestinal, or disseminated disease. Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form. The initial presentation is nonspecific with eye or facial pain and facial numbness followed by conjunctival suffusion and dimunition of vision. If untreated it can spread from the sinuses to the orbit, and to the frontal lobe, and may also cause cavernous sinus thrombosis. On examination, sinuses may look normal in initial stages, and may need blind bipsy. In later stages, there is erythema (with or without edema), followed by a necrotic eschar.

Diagnosis is made by culturing the organisms from the sterile sites like needle aspirate, pleural fluid, or a tissue biopsy specimen. The biopsy is most sensitive. It reveals characteristic wide, thick-walled, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

Management:

  • Amphotericin B is the first line, antifungal agent. The dose of liposomal amphotericin formulation is 5-10mg/kg/day. Other antifungal agents used are isavuconazole and posaconazole
  • Treatment of the underlying risk factors
  • Surgical debridement

questions.text: During the clinical examination of an elderly male patient with bilateral pitting pedal edema, a 3.7 cm rise of jugulovenous pulse is noted on gentle compression with the palm over the abdomen for about 30 seconds. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign is called positive hepatojugular reflux.

It is elicited by applying firm pressure over the liver for 15 to 30 seconds while observing the neck veins for increasing jugular venous pressure (JVP). This reflux indicates that the right ventricle cannot accommodate the increase in venous pressure.  

This sign is positive in right heart failure and severe tricuspid regurgitation. Additionally, there are prominent V waves and Y descent in tricuspid regurgitation.

JVP is measured as the distance between the top of jugular venous pulsation and the sternal angle of Louis. The normal height of JVP is between 6 cm to 8 cm H2O. 

Other options:

Option A - A large pericardial effusion can compress the base of the left lung. This is noted as Ewart's sign - an area of dullness and increased fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula. 

Option C & D - Friedrich's sign and Kussmaul's sign are both seen in constrictive pericarditis. Friedreich's sign is the prominent y descent of the jugular venous waveform, and Kussmaul's sign is the rise (or lack of fall) of JVP with inspiration. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: You are an intern working in the emergency department. Your resident asks you to insert Foley's catheter in a patient. You try inserting orange coded Foleys catheter but it is not possible to insert. You ask a paramedical staff to get a smaller catheter. Which one of the following catheter would you ask for?
questions.solution:
The Foley's catheter coded with green color is smaller than the orange colored one. Therefore, this should be used in the patient. All other colors mentioned are larger than the orange coded catheters.

The size of the urine catheters are measured by French (Fr).  The French scale refers to the external diameter of the catheter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

In a patient, if there is difficulty in catheterization, a lower Fr number should be used instead.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presents with fever, headache, cough with scanty sputum, and a sore throat for the past 2 weeks. He also complains of multiple joint pains. A chest x-ray is shown below. Culture shows a fried egg appearance on PPLO agar. Which of the following treatment options would not be recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with symptoms of a URTI, arthralgias, and culture showing fried egg appearance on PPLO agar is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by mycoplasma. It does not warrant the use of ciprofloxacin as treatment.

Mycoplasma is a major cause of atypical pneumonia in both children and adults. Clinically it has a very non-specific presentation and commonly presents with URTI (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis), wheezing, and cough. It is also characterized by its extrapulmonary manifestations. Extrapulmonary manifestations include cold agglutinin disease (IgM mediated AIHA), Erythema multiforme or SJS, arthralgia with adenopathy, Guillain-Barre syndrome, myocarditis, pericarditis, and encephalitis.

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest x-rays. On chest x-ray, the most common pattern is that of peribronchial pneumonia with thickened bronchial markings, streaky interstitial infiltrations, and sub-segmental atelectasis. On PPLO agar (Dienes method) it shows a biphasic with fried-egg appearance.

Treatment options for Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection include:

  • Macrolides (e.g. azithromycin)
  • Tetracyclines (e.g. doxycycline)
  • Respiratory fluoroquinolones (e.g. levofloxacin)

Azithromycin is the drug of choice for management. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

However, ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin are not recommended because of their high minimal inhibitory concentrations against Mycoplasma pneumoniae isolates and their poor performance in experimental studies.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was referred to cardiology OPD for the management of hypertension. His BP was not controlled with spironolactone and laboratory investigations revealed hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis. His BP comes down when spironolactone is replaced with amiloride. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, responding to amiloride but not spironolactone, a diagnosis of Liddle syndrome (also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism) is most likely.

Liddle syndrome is due to the autosomal dominant gain of function mutation in epithelium sodium channel, ENaC, in collecting tubules. It classically causes hypertension in young patients, along with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The disease responds to amiloride but is resistant to spironolactone. Although its presentation is similar to primary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone is nearly undetectable in the serum due to negative feedback. Hence it is also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism.

Other options:

Option A: Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME) occurs due to the activation of mineralocorticoid receptors by cortisol, like in 11-β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. It also presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, but mineralocorticoid receptor blockade with spironolactone is successful in treating SAME. Spironolactone does not work in Liddle syndrome because the defect is downstream to where spironolactone acts.

Option C: Addison's disease refers to adrenal insufficiency and decreased levels of aldosterone. It presents with hyponatremic volume contraction (which may lead to hypotension), hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular reabsorption defect in Na+/K+/2Cl- channel. It causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis. But BP is usually low to normal. It mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: Which among the following is true regarding the vaccine shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Clinical trials have shown that the Sputnik V vaccine has an efficacy of around 97.6% efficacy. 

Sputnik V vaccine contains replication-deficient adenovirus of serotypes 26 and 5. The vaccine can be stored at a temperature of +2 to +8 degrees Celsius. The standard regimen is two doses of vaccine which are given 21 days apart. It is shown to have around 97.6% efficacy.

Important authorized COVID 19 vaccines

Vaccines Mechanism

Sputnik Light Recombinant adenovirus vaccine with serotypes 26

The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) in January 2021, has granted permission for restricted emergency use of the following vaccines against COVID-19:

questions.text:
A woman is brought to the casualty in an unconscious state. Her arterial blood gas analysis report reveals the following values. Among the given conditions, which of the following can lead to this clinical scenario?
  • pH- 7.32
  • pCO2- 36 mm Hg
  • HCO3- - 18 mEq/L
  • Sodium levels- 136 mEq/L
  • Chloride levels- 109 mEq/L
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap. Among the given options, diarrhea will lead to this scenario as diarrhea causes loss of bicarbonates.

The diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.32 indicates acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 18 mmol/L

Step 3: Arterial pCO2 is within the normal range.

Therefore the patient has metabolic acidosis.

Step 4: Calculate the anion gap. 

Anion gap = Na+-(Cl-+HCO3-)

= 136-(109+18)

= 9, which is a normal anion gap.

Causes of normal anion gap acidosis (NAGMA) are:

  • Diarrhea
  • External pancreatic or small-bowel drainage
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy, jejunal loop, ileal loop
  • Drugs- Calcium chloride, magnesium sulfate, cholestyramine
  • Proximal and distal renal tubular acidosis
  • Potassium-sparing diuretics
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers

Causes of high anionic gap acidosis (HAGMA) are:

  • Methanol poisoning
  • Uremia- renal failure
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Propylene glycol
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethanol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning

Other options:

Options A, C, and D: This will give rise to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has been recommended by the Government of India for the treatment of Covid19 infection, but not recommended by WHO?
questions.solution:
Hydroxychloroquine has been recommended by the Govt. of India for the treatment of mild Covid 19 infection. According to this, hydroxychloroquine should be given 400 mg twice daily for 1 day, followed by 400 mg daily for the next 4 days, unless contraindicated. But according to the WHO, hydroxychloroquine must not be used in the management of Covid19 infection. According to WHO, the use of hydroxychloroquine might prevent the use of other drugs like azithromycin and fluoroquinolones, which also have QT-prolonging adverse effects. It does not appear to reduce mortality, the need for mechanical ventilation, or hospitalization.

As of now, even ivermectin is not recommended by WHO for the treatment of Covid 19. It allows the administration of Covid 19 for clinical trial purposes only.

Other drugs like antipyretics, heparin, and corticosteroids have been recommended by both government of India and WHO for the treatment of Covid 19 infection. However, the dose of corticosteroids recommended by the WHO and CDC is 6 mg dexamethasone or 32 mg of methylprednisolone, whereas GOI recommends methylprednisolone 0.5 to 1 mg/kg or IV dexamethasone 0.1 to 0.2 mg/kg.

Currently, remdesivir does not have enough evidence about its efficacy in the treatment of the disease. Further, the availability of the drug is limited. Therefore, according to both Government of India and WHO, it is not routinely used in all patients with Covid-19. If the administration is considered, contraindications like ALT >5 times normal at baseline or renal eGFR <30 mL/minute should not be present.

 

Drugs WHO Government of India
Hydroxychloroquine Not recommended Recommended
Ivermectin For clinical trials only Recommended

Antipyretics

Anticoagulants

Corticosteroids

 Recommended Recommended
Remdesivir

Not used in all patients

(Conditional recommendation)

 Not used in all patients

questions.text: A young patient presented with polyuria and polydipsia. His BP is 130/80 mm Hg. Laboratory parameters revealed serum K+ of 3.2 mmol/L, blood pH of 7.46, and hypomagnesemia. Urinary calcium was elevated. He is not on any medications. This condition is likely due to a defect in which of the following?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Bartter syndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the thick ascending loop of Henle. It results in the following features:

  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Natriuresis with high aldosterone (due to RAAS activation)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypomagnesemia 
  • Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria

The clinical features of this condition are similar to the effects of loop diuretics. These drugs also act on the Na+/K+/Cl- channel. Hence, response to loop diuretics may be blunted. Treatment is with potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone and amiloride. NSAID's like indomethacin are second line drugs however they can reduce renal function.

Option A: Defect in the proximal tubule results in Fanconi's syndrome. These patients have acidosis, with glycosuria, generalized aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia.

Option B: Defect in the Na+/Cl- cotransporter in distal convoluted tubule (DCT) results in Gitelman syndrome. These patients also present with hypokalemic alkalosis and hypomagnesemia. However, they also develop, hypocalciuria, and chondrocalcinosis.

Option D: Increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) channels results in Liddle syndrome. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/ μL. He is complaining of breathlessness for the past 3 days. A chest radiograph was taken and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region. This finding along with the CD4 count of 170 cells /μL makes pneumocystis pneumonia as the most likely diagnosis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

The classic radiographic appearance of symptomatic pneumocystis pneumonia consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Histopathology of the tissue will show foamy alveolar infiltrate and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates, which is pathognomonic of PCP. Specific stains like methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa can show the cysts. Other tests which are used for the diagnosis of PCP are polymerase chain reaction, (1→3)-β-d-glucan, etc.

The treatment and prevention of PCP are with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Other options

Option A- Mycobacterium avium complex infection is generally seen when the CD4 count falls less than 50 cells/μL. CT scan of the infected lung will show peribronchial inflammation, which gives rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures). In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Below image- Tree in bud appearance which is indicated by an arrowhead.

Option B- Histoplasmosis occurs when the CD4 count falls below 150 cells/μL and high risk populations in endemic areas or those with occupational exposure. Chest radiograph shows the signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia commonly appears as lobar or segmental consolidation. In some, it can involve more than one lobe. It can have pleural effusion and empyema in severe cases.

Below image- Consolidation in streptococcal pneumonia

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient complaints of fatigue and recurrent infections. He also notes epistaxis, visual disturbances and peripheral neuropathy. Peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation and marrow biopsy shows Dutcher bodies. Coomb's test is also positive. Which of the following malignancies does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The malignancy that the patient most likely has is Waldenström's macroglobulinemia.

Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a neoplasm of small lymphocytes and a variable number of IgM-secreting plasma cells. It occurs in older adults. It most commonly occurs in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. It can also be associated with viral infections.

It occurs due to MYD88 L265P somatic mutation. Diffuse marrow infiltration by plasma cells, plasmacytoid lymphocytes, and lymphocytes (all from the same clone) is observed. Normocytic normochromic anaemia is seen with rouleaux formation. Coomb's test is positive. Cells do not form tumor masses or produce lytic lesions. There is hyperviscocity of blood.

Clinical features include lymphadenopathy, hyperviscosity of blood, hepatosplenomegaly, epistaxis, transient paresis, visual disturbance and other non specific symptoms like headache, dizziness, and weakness.

Investigations typically reveal increased levels of IgM. Lymphocytes commonly contain Dutcher bodies (intranuclear inclusions). Bence–Jones proteins are found in 20–30%. Coomb's test is positive. M’ or monoclonal spike is seen. Treatment is usually required when the patient is symptomatic and the preferred drug is ibrutinib. Other first-line drugs include rituximab and bortezomib.

Other options:

Option A: Diffuse large B cell lymphoma is characterized by the presence of large B cells with vesicular chromatin and distinct nucleoli.

Option B: Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by a starry sky appearance due to the spread of reactive macrophages around the tumor cells against the background of pale cytoplasm. 

Option C: Follicular lymphoma - This is characterized by nodules of varying size with a cleaved nucleus and is composed of lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was referred with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. Bone marrow aspirate could not be obtained despite multiple attempts, hence a bone marrow biopsy was done. The findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the deposition of numerous collagen fibers in the bone marrow, which indicates marrow fibrosis. These clinical findings and history of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration are diagnostic of primary myelofibrosis.

In this condition, the neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells results in increased and abnormal proliferation of the megakaryocytes. These megakaryocytes release excessive amounts of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-β. Increased growth factors lead to the deposition of collagen in the bone marrow which eventually leads to fibrosis. 

The clinical features include:

  • Early phase:
    • Thrombocytosis (large, abnormal platelets) and leukocytosis
    • Hypercellularity of bone marrow
  • Late phase:
    • Pancytopenia 
    • Hypocellularity and fibrosis of bone marrow (dry tap)
    • Teardrop-shaped RBCs and leukoerythroblastosis (premature release of nucleated erythroid and early granulocytes into blood)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly - due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

The FDA approved fedratinib, a JAK2-selective inhibitor for the treatment of adult patients with intermediate or high-risk primary or secondary myelofibrosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with complaints of cough with sputum, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. There is a history of repeated lung and sinus infections since childhood. His BMI is 18 kg/m2 and has bilateral nasal polyps. Both lungs have coarse rhonchi and a chest radiograph shows evidence of bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis. To confirm the suspected diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, which of the following is the next best investigation of choice?

choices.text: Isolation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on repeated sputum cultures

questions.solution:
In a suspected case of cystic fibrosis, a sweat chloride value is the investigation of choice. Values >60 mmol/L are diagnostic. 

The primary clinical manifestations of cystic fibrosis (CF) are due to the effects of the mutated cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, and pancreas. This protein is a large transmembrane protein involved in the transport of chloride and other ions. Hence, abnormalities of the CFTR lead to abnormalities of salt and water transport.

In the lungs, abnormal CFTR leads to thick, sticky mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance. The patient will have recurrent respiratory infections with the development of bronchiectasis.

The standard test commonly performed to diagnose CF is the sweat chloride test. Elevated values are pathognomonic of this condition, with a cut-off of >60 mmol/L in adults being diagnostic. Values in the range 30–59 mmol/L fall within the indeterminate range.

A large number of mutations can cause CF, therefore genetic testing can be expensive and is not the first test performed for diagnosis when CF is suspected. A negative sweat chloride test does not exclude the diagnosis. In case of high suspicion of CF and a negative sweat test, alternative diagnostic studies such as measurement of nasal membrane potential difference, semen analysis, or assessment of pancreatic function may be done. All patients diagnosed with cystic fibrosis should undergo CFTR genotyping.

Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF but is not specific for the diagnosis because bronchiectasis from any other cause can lead to P. aeruginosa infection.

Categories of CFTR mutations

Classes of defects in the CFTR gene include:

  • the absence of synthesis (class I)
  • defective protein maturation and premature degradation (class II)
  • disordered gating/regulation, such as diminished adenosine triphosphate (ATP) binding and hydrolysis (class III)
  • defective conductance through the ion channel pore (class IV)
  • a reduced number of CFTR transcripts due to a promoter or splicing abnormality (class V)
  • accelerated turnover from the cell surface (class VI).

questions.text: A patient is admitted for myocardial infarction complicated by severe mitral regurgitation. He suddenly develops shortness of breath, decreased urine output, and drowsiness. Blood pressure is 86/40 mmHg, pulse 120 bpm, and respiratory rate 24 per minute. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Up to 40% of cardiac output may be distributed to the respiratory muscles
Patient will develop type 2 respiratory failure
Intubation and mechanical ventilation are treatment of choice
Batwing appearance can be expected on an x-ray

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cardiogenic shock. He is likely to develop type 4 respiratory failure, not type 2. 

Patients in cardiogenic shock often have respiratory distress secondary to acute pulmonary edema (batwing appearance on x-ray). This increases the requirement of oxygen delivery to the respiratory muscles from <5% to up to 40% of cardiac output.

Hypoperfusion and increased oxygen requirement lead to inadequate perfusion of respiratory muscles which causes type 4 respiratory failure.

Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of rheumatic fever is found to have a loud S1 and a mid-diastolic murmur which is best heard at the apex in the left lateral recumbent position. If the chest radiograph is performed in this patient, which of the following features is least likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Kerley B lines more prominent in upper lung fields
Prominence of the main pulmonary artery
Straightening of upper left cardiac border
Dilation of the upper lobe pulmonary veins

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of mitral stenosis. Kerley B lines are dense, short, horizontal lines most frequently seen in lower and middle lung fields.

Radiographic findings of mitral stenosis are:

  • Straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette
  • Prominence of the main pulmonary artery 
  • Dilation of the upper lobe pulmonary veins
  • Posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged left atrium.
  • Kerley B lines- These are dense, short, horizontal lines most frequently seen in lower and middle lung fields

Auscultatory findings in mitral stenosis

  • The first heart sound (S1) is accentuated
  • The opening snap (OS) is after A2 sound. It is best heard during the expiration and at the apex of the heart
  • The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur, which is heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position. This murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis.
  • If the patient also has mitral regurgitation, a systolic murmur can be heard at or medial to the apex. 

ECG tracing will show tall and peak T waves due to left atrial enlargement. It might also show the features of severe pulmonary hypertension, right axis deviation and RV hypertrophy.

Below image shows Kerley B lines (white arrows)

questions.text: The protein that is defective in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is:
questions.solution:
The protein that is defective in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is polycystin. There is a mutation in the PKD1 and PKD2 genes, which code for the proteins polycystin-1 (PC1) and polycystin-2 (PC2) respectively.

The patients will develop cortical and medullary renal cysts, liver cysts, pancreatic cysts, hypertension, and subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Other options:

Options A and C- Fibrocystin/Polyductin is a large integral membrane protein that is coded by the PKHD1 gene. Defect in this protein leads to autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. It is generally diagnosed in utero. The babies will have decreased urine production leading to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia. Many babies die within 1st month of life.

Option D - Tuberin is a protein coded by the gene TSC2. Defects in this protein can tuberous sclerosis. They can have kidney cysts, renal angiomyolipoma, and renal cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text:
A young man visits the fever clinic with a history of high-grade fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite for the past 5 days. He also feels breathless after walking around 50m. On examination, the patient has a SpO2 of 92 on room air. He does not have any history of lung disease or tobacco smoking. his respiratory rate is found to be 25 per minute. Rapid antigen test for Covid 19 was found to positive. His renal and liver function tests are within normal limits. Which of the following is correct regarding the management of this patient?
  1. Antipyretics
  2. Methylprednisolone- 2mg/kg per day
  3. Enoxaparin-0.5mg/kg per day
  4. CRP and D-dimer 48 to 72 hourly
  5. Remdesivir
questions.solution:
The patient has a SpO2 of 92% on room air and a respiratory rate of 25 per minute. He has moderate Covid disease. Moderate Covid19 infection should be treated with 

  • Symptomatic treatment such as antipyretic (paracetamol) for fever and pain, anti-tussive for cough. Continue medications for co-morbid conditions.
  • Adequate hydration to be ensured
  • Oxygen Support: Target SpO2: 92-96% (88-92% in patients with COPD).
  • Anticoagulation-prophylactic dose of un-fractionated heparin (UFH) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) (e.g enoxaparin 0.5 mg /Kg body wt per day SC)
  • Anti-inflammatory or immunomodulatory therapy- IV methylprednisolone 0.5 to 1 mg/kg or IV dexamethasone 0.1 to 0.2 mg/kg usually for a duration of 5 to 10 days.
  • Antibiotics should not be prescribed routinely unless there is clinical suspicion of a bacterial infection.
  • Awake proning: should be encouraged in all patients who require supplemental oxygen therapy. Typical protocols include 30–120 minutes in the prone position, followed by 30–120 minutes in left lateral decubitus, right lateral decubitus, and upright sitting position.
  • Monitoring for hemodynamic instability, change in oxygen requirement. HRCT chest to be done only if there is worsening.
  • Lab monitoring: Monitor CRP and D-dimer 48 to 72 hourly, and complete blood count, renal and liver function tests 24 to 48 hourly. IL-6 levels should be done if the patient is deteriorating.
  • Remdesivir may be considered in patients who have
    • symptoms for less than 10 days
    • moderate to a severe disease requiring supplemental oxygen
    • Not pregnant and not lactating
    • No renal or hepatic impairment (eGFR <30 ml/min/m2; AST/ALT >5 times upper limit of normal
    • Dose: 200 mg IV on day 1 followed by 100 mg IV daily for 4 days (total 5 days)

questions.text:
A young woman delivered a baby at 34 weeks of gestation due to abruptio placenta. After four days of delivery, she developed bleeding from venipuncture sites, petechiae, and ecchymoses over her body. The lab findings and the peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb- 12 mg/dL
WBC count- 10000/cu. mm
Platelet count- 90,000/μL
Prothrombin time- 17s
Activated partial thromboplastin time: 47 s
Elevated fibrin degraded products
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

DIC is characterised by widespread intravascular fibrin formation. The most common causes are bacterial sepsis, obstetric causes (abruptio placenta, amniotic fluid embolism), and malignancies like acute promyelocytic leukaemia.

Exposure of blood to phospholipids from damaged tissue, hemolysis, and endothelial damage leads to the exposure of tissue factors and the generation of thrombin. Thrombin generation leads to fibrin deposition in the small blood vessels, activation of coagulation factors, and consumption of platelets.

Patients will have bleeding manifestations due to decreased platelet counts. The most common findings are bleeding ranging from oozing from venipuncture sites, petechiae, and ecchymoses to severe haemorrhage from the gastrointestinal tract, lung, or central nervous system.

Laboratory investigations in DIC

  • Decreased platelet count 
  • Prolonged prothrombin time PT/TT
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
  • Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers)
  • Peripheral smear shows schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) 

Other options

Option A- Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is the autoimmune destruction of the platelets. It may be primary or may occur secondarily due to autoimmune disorders, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and infections, such as HIV and hepatitis C. They will also have a low platelet count. However, a peripheral smear may show large platelets with otherwise normal morphology.

Option B- Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is characterised by pentad- microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA), thrombocytopenia, neurologic symptoms, fever, and renal failure. The pathophysiology of TTP involves the accumulation of ultra-large multimers of von Willebrand factor as a result of decreased activity of the plasma proteases. These multimers cause MAHA. The coagulation tests are normal, and fibrin-degraded products are not elevated.

Option D- Factor V is normally inactivated by protein C. Factor V Leiden mutation results in resistance to the inactivation by protein C. This leads to abnormally high levels of factor V, leading to thrombosis. The patients may have thromboses like deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary thrombosis.

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting.  On examination, pulse rate is 58/min and BP is 90/60 mmHg. His ECG is shown below. Cardiac biomarkers showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is inferior wall MI based on the given presentation of chest pain, bradycardia (pulse rate 58/min), hypotension (BP 90/60 mm Hg), elevated cardiac biomarkers, and ECG changes (ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, aVF, with reciprocal change in lead aVL). 

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. While anterior infarction shows sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and hypertension), the inferior wall MI shows parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension).

The table below gives the localization of MI and probable vessel involved based on ECG findings.

Location of MI Leads Affected Vessel Involved
Anterior wall V2 to V4 Left Anterior Descending artery 
– Diagonal branch
Septal wall V1 and V2 Left Anterior Descending artery 
– Septal branch
Lateral wall I, aVL, V5, V6 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch
Inferior wall II, III, aVF Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch
Posterior wall V1 to V4 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch

Patients with pericarditis also present with severe chest pain and ST-segment elevations. However, this ST-segment elevation has upward concavity with depression of the PR segment.

An ECG showing pericarditis is given below.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4
