questions.text: A young male patient visits the flu and fever clinic with a history of fever, anorexia, cough, and difficulty in breathing for the past 4 days. On examination, he is found to have a respiratory rate of 27 per minute and SpO2 of 88% on room air. He does not smoke cigarettes. His RT-PCR test was found to be positive for COVID-19 disease. According to the Ministry of Health and Family welfare guidelines, this patient has:
questions.solution:
SpO2 of less than 90% on room air is classified as severe COVID-19 infection according to Indian guidelines. 

Classification of COVID-19 infection severity (Indian guidelines):

Mild- patients with uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection, may have mild symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, nasal congestion, malaise, headache. There is no shortness of breath or hypoxia.

Moderate- Patients have pneumonia with no signs of severe disease. Adults with the presence of clinical features of dyspnea and or hypoxia, fever, cough, including SpO2 90 to ≤93% on room air, Respiratory Rate more or equal to 24 per minute.

Severe- Adults show clinical signs of pneumonia with one of the following; respiratory rate >30 breaths/min, severe respiratory distress, SpO2 <90% on room air.

Severe infection further has:

  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome- patients develop new or worsening respiratory symptoms within one week of onset of the symptoms. There are opacities in the chest radiographs which are not due to effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules. The patients develop respiratory failure which is not due to cardiac failure or fluid overload. The oxygen impairment in adults will be PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O).
  • Sepsis- Life-threatening organ dysfunction caused due to an infection.
  • Septic shock- Persisting hypotension despite fluid resuscitation. Patients require vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg and serum lactate level > 2 mmol/L.

Mild cases can be managed at COVID care centres or home isolated. Moderate and severe cases will require hospitalisation in a dedicated COVID hospital.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice that the jugular venous pressure (JVP) does not fall during inspiration and in fact, shows a paradoxical rise. Which of the following clinical conditions is least likely to be associated with the clinical finding seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration is known as Kussmaul's sign. It is not seen in Dilated Cardiomyopathy. 

Normally, in inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure, the JVP falls. When there is an impairment in the filling or expansion of the right ventricle or a raise in the right atrial pressure, the blood backs up in the jugular veins. The backpressure causes an elevation or a failure in the appropriate fall in JVP during inspiration. It is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

It is also a common, isolated finding in patients after cardiac surgery without other hemodynamic abnormalities.

questions.text: A 17-year-old student comes to the clinic with a history of four episodes of arthritis involving large joints and was recently admitted for new-onset atrial fibrillation. A holosystolic murmur with early diastolic rumbling is heard at the apex. An early diastolic murmur is also heard at the right second intercostal space near the sternal edge. Which of the following is recommended for long-term prophylaxis of the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has clinical features and a history suggestive of recurrent episodes of acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Monthly penicillin G injections are recommended for long-term prophylaxis.

The findings of mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation indicate the diagnosis of ARF. The presence of atrial fibrillation indicates severe rheumatic heart disease. Prophylaxis with either oral phenoxymethylpenicillin (250 mg twice daily) or preferably, benzathine benzylpenicillin (1.2 million U IM monthly) is considered the best method to prevent further episodes of ARF, and therefore prevent further valvular damage.

ARF is an autoimmune disease that develops in response to group A streptococcal infection. It is commonly seen in children between the age of 5-14 years. An upper respiratory tract infection with some M serotypes of the organism is the trigger. The concept of molecular mimicry is used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. 

Since one attack of ARF increases the risk for further episodes and development of RHD, secondary prophylaxis is recommended by the American heart association (AHA) as follows:

  • Rheumatic fever without carditis: For 5 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer). 
  • Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual valvular disease: For 10 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer).
  • Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, evident clinically or on echocardiography: For 10 years after the last attack or till the age of 40 (whichever is longer). Sometimes lifelong prophylaxis can be given.

Symptoms usually present after a latent period of about three weeks. Indolent carditis and chorea are the exceptions that can present even six months later. Migratory asymmetric polyarthritis which affects large joints and high-grade fever are common features. Cutaneous manifestations include erythema marginatum and subcutaneous nodules. Sydenham's chorea is commonly found in females and frequently affects the head and upper limbs.

Other options:

Option A: Glucocorticoids are recommended at a dose of 1–2 mg/kg per day (maximum, 80 mg), usually for a few days or up to a maximum of 3 weeks.

Option C: Doxycycline is not a first-line agent for group A Streptococcus, the pathogen that causes ARF.

Option D: Daily aspirin is the treatment of choice for the migratory arthritis of large joints and fever which are common manifestations of ARF. 

 

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male student with cystic fibrosis developed acute onset cough which was worsening progressively, along with wheezing and increased sputum production. A probable diagnosis of of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) has been made. Which of the following is the incorrect option regarding the serological diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) in a patient with cystic fibrosis. ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the detection of aspergillum-specific IgE or positive skin prick test and serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml. IgG antibodies to Aspergillus flavus are seen in chronic aspergillus sinusitis.

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis:

ABPA is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonisation of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma (~2.5% of patients) or cystic fibrosis (up to 15%). In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis and respiratory compromise.

With the development of ABPA, asthma or CF typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts.

The presence of hyperattenuated mucus in airways is highly specific. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:

  • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
  • Positive skin prick test in response to A.fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with a history of high-grade fever for the last 5 days. She was recently diagnosed with a ventricular septal defect. On examination, a new regurgitant murmur is heard and an echocardiogram shows the presence of a mass on the mitral valve. When her hands were examined, the following lesions were seen which were painful. What are these lesions known as?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient would be infective endocarditis (IE). The image shows erythematous, nodular lesions located in the pads of the fingers which are painful. These are known as Osler nodes. It occurs due to immune complex deposition and vasculitis.

Patients with infective endocarditis can have cardiac or non-cardiac manifestations.

Cardiac manifestations of IE:

  • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
  • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
  • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- This is caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
  • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
  • Embolization of coronary arteries

Noncardiac manifestations of IE are:

  • Arterial emboli- causing pain of ischemia of the organs
  • Osler's nodes -are painful, red, nodular lesions usually located in the pads of the fingers and toes
  • Roth's spots- retinal hemorrhages with a pale center
  • Janeway lesions- In contrast to Osler's nodes, these are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are commonly associated with staphylococcal IE.
  • Splenic abscess
  • Cerebral abscess
  • Immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis
  • Positivity for rheumatoid factor
  • Petechiae on oral and conjunctival mucosa
  • Splinter subungual hemorrhages-painless, dark red lines in the nailbed.
  • Mycotic aneurysms
  • Splenomegaly

Below image- Janeway lesions (Option A)

Below image- Roth Spots (Option C)

The Woronoff ring (Option D) is the clear peripheral zone around the plaques, seen in psoriasis.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A young man presents to the hospital with complaints of profuse diarrhea for the past 2 days. He says that he had been to Goa and had tried seafood and shellfish. There is no fever. He says that the stool appears watery and gray. The result of the test is shown in the image below. What is the antibiotic of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the test are suggestive of cholera infection. The test shown in the above image is the String test performed to identify the colonies of Vibrio cholerae. Erythromycin and azithromycin are the antibiotics of choice in this patient.

Cholera is a diarrheal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae serogroup O1 or O139. It is commonly acquired by eating contaminated water and shellfish. The incubation period is around 24- 48 hours. 

Patients may be asymptomatic or have only mild diarrhea. Others present with the sudden onset of explosive and life-threatening diarrhea (cholera gravis). They usually complain of sudden onset of painless watery diarrhea which can become voluminous. It is associated with vomiting. Fever is usually absent. 

The stool has a characteristic appearance. It appears gray, slightly cloudy fluid with flecks of mucus, no blood, and has a fishy odor. It has been called a “rice-water” stool because it resembles the water in which rice has been washed.

The selective media of the organism is as taurocholate–tellurite–gelatin (TTG) agar or thiosulfate–citrate–bile salts–sucrose (TCBS) agar.

Treatment involves rehydration with oral rehydration solution or ringer's lactate. Erythromycin and azithromycin are the antibiotic agents of choice.

Other options:

Option A- Ciprofloxacin is used in the treatment of shigellosis. The patient may have a fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody mucopurulent stools.

Option C- Streptomycin is used in the treatment of brucellosis. It is a zoonotic disease and is caused by exposure to infected animals or their products. It can be due to ingestion, inhalation, or mucosal or percutaneous exposure. It presents as a fever with profuse sweating, especially at night.

Option D- Ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of enteric fever. It presents as headache, chills, malaise, arthralgia, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. On examination, they may have a faint, salmon-coloured, blanching, maculopapular rash located primarily on the trunk and hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: A patient presents with high colored urine. A urine dipstick test done was positive. On further evaluation by centrifugation at 2000rpm for 5 min, the sample was still high colored but became colorless after about 3 hours.  Which among the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Myoglobinuria is most likely in this patient.

A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme which is present in red blood cells, haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or due to porphyrias.

Myoglobinuria is the presence of an excess amount of myoglobin in the urine. It is mostly caused by muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury. 

Causes of myoglobinuria:

  • Physical causes are trauma, crush injury, heatstroke, hypothermia, malignant hyperthermia, extensive burns, seizures, strenuous exercise, and prolonged immobility.
  • Non-physical causes include hypoxic injury, metabolic disturbances, genetic disorders, infections, drugs, and toxins.

The primary goal of treatment in the case of myoglobinuria is to prevent acute kidney injury (AKI), and for that, the initial therapy is mainly focused on rehydration to facilitate the renal clearance of myoglobin.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following finding. Which of the following conditions is the patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is clubbing, hence the patient is unlikely to have COPD. Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. 

In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD then a possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window gets obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

questions.text: Which is the most common arrhythmia after reperfusion of an occluded coronary artery by fibrinolytic therapy?
questions.solution:
Accelerated idioventricular rhythm (AIVR) is the most common arrhythmia noted after reperfusion of an occluded coronary artery by fibrinolytic therapy.

AIVR is defined as a ventricular escape rhythm with a rate between 60 and 100 beats/min. It is referred to as “slow ventricular tachycardia”. It can appear in up to 20% of patients with acute MI, most commonly in the first 2 days after presentation.

Episodes of AIVR have not been found to affect prognosis in acute MI and usually do not require intervention. If AIVR is accompanied by hemodynamic compromise, treatment with atropine or atrial pacing will often suppress the rhythm.

questions.text: A female patient on medication for recurrent muscle pain presents with hematuria and flank pain. Investigations revealed a shrunken kidney with papillary necrosis and calcification. Which of the following drugs was she most likely on?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the findings of papillary calcifications and necrosis is suggestive of analgesic nephropathy. The patient was most likely on phenacetin-aspirin-caffeine.

Analgesic nephropathy is a renal disease characterized by tubulointerstitial nephritis and renal papillary necrosis. It occurs due to excessive prolonged use of a combination of analgesics, especially phenacetin-aspirin-caffeine. Paracetamol is another drug that is implicated. It is more common in women and a history of chronic headaches, arthralgias, and abdominal pain which necessitated the chronic use is usually present. 

Flank pain with or without hematuria might indicate a ureteral obstruction due to the sloughed papilla secondary to necrosis. It increases the risk for urinary tract malignancies. 

NSAIDs are a group of drugs with analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic properties. The effects are exerted by blocking the synthesis of prostaglandins. The COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes are inhibited. These enzymes are the first steps in the production of prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins.

Other side effects of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) include agranulocytosis, cystitis, hematuria, thrombosis, and dyspepsia.  

Other options:

Options A and C: Both cyclosporine and tacrolimus are calcineurin inhibitors (CNI), used as immunosuppressants that can cause CNI nephrotoxicity. Acute kidney injury can be due to thrombotic microangiopathy or toxic tubulopathy. Chronic CNI nephrotoxicity is seen commonly in transplant patients. It presents with a decline in glomerular filtration rate, hypertension, and hyperkalemia.

Option D: Lithium, commonly used in manic-depressive disorders can lead to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients present with polyuria and polydipsia. Rarely, it can cause tubulointerstitial nephritis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient who is a known case of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and vomiting. The patient is agitated and her blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Ophthalmoscopy reveals the presence of papilledema. Which of the following antihypertensive is least useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario points towards the diagnosis of malignant hypertension. The drug which is least useful in the management is furosemide(diuretic). 

Volume depletion is common in patients with malignant hypertension, and the administration of a diuretic together with a hypertensive agent can lead to an extreme drop in blood pressure.

Diuretics are generally not recommended for the rapid reduction of blood pressure in patients with hypertensive crises. They are used only in conditions of volume overload such as acute pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the Emergency room with a 3-day history of fever with chills, cough with production of rusty sputum, and dyspnoea on exertion. There is no history of contact with an infected person. His examination reveals fever 103° F, heart rate 112/min, respiratory rate 27/min, blood pressure 84/42 mm Hg, oxygen saturation on room air 82%. The blood test shows leucocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and elevated parameters of coagulation. He has metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. The chest x-ray shows focal consolidation bilaterally. Due to the worsening of his condition, he is intubated and placed on a ventilator. He is diagnosed to have acute respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following statements is true in this case?

choices.text: Respiratory failure is the most common cause of death in ARDS
The pulmonary consolidation affects lung apices predominantly
Responds to increasing concentration of oxygen inhalation
A high level of neutrophils is seen in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid

questions.solution:
In patients with ARDS, there is an inflammatory response in the lungs leading to high levels of neutrophils and their secretory products in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. This is characteristic of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is characterized by rapid onset dyspnea, hypoxemia, and diffuse lung infiltrates resulting in respiratory failure. ARDS is caused by diffuse lung injury due to varied causes like inhalation injury, pneumonia, gastric aspiration, pulmonary contusion, burns, pancreatitis, and sepsis.

An early chest x-ray typically reveals diffuse opacities due to consolidation. Later these opacities progress to more extensive and asymmetrical consolidation. The CT scan of lungs shows heterogeneous involvement and predominantly affects gravity-dependent areas.

The affected airspaces are filled with fluid and cannot contribute to ventilation, leading to hypoxaemia (due to increased pulmonary shunt) and hypercapnia (due to inadequate ventilation in some areas of the lung); resulting in, ventilation–perfusion mismatch.

The hypoxemia in ARDS is refractory to increasing concentration of inhaled oxygen that occurs due to increased intrapulmonary shunting of blood.

The most common cause of death is sepsis in ARDS. Due to improvement in ventilator support systems, respiratory failure causes mortality in less than 20% of cases.

questions.text: A worker from the shipbuilding industry has developed difficulty in breathing. He has been working there for the past 12 years. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern with a decrease in lung volumes and diffusing capacity. A chest X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of breathlessness with the pulmonary function test revealing the restrictive pattern of the disease and the X-ray showing a holly-leaf appearance is suggestive of asbestosis.

Asbestosis is an occupational disease and is characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lung that is related to the intensity and duration of exposure to asbestos. It is seen in people who work in the shipbuilding, processing, construction, and mining industries. At least 10 years of exposure to asbestosis is needed to develop the disease. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Radiologically it presents as pleural plaques, irregular or linear opacities, and ground-glass appearance particularly present at the lower lung fields. HRCT will show the presence of pleural plaque, subpleural curvilinear lines 5–10 mm in length that appears to be parallel to the pleura. Asbestosis increases the risk of development of mesothelioma.

Other options

Option A- Silicosis is an occupational disease and is caused by exposure to silica. It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying. It presents as small rounded opacities in the upper lobe. There may be calcification of hilar lymph nodes which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

The below image shows the crazy-paving pattern in silicosis.

 

Option B- Chronic berylliosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to beryllium. It is seen in people who work on processing alloys for high-tech industries. Chest radiography shows nodules along the septal lines.

Option D- Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP) is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to coal dust. It is seen in people working in mines. It presents as small opacities in the upper lobe of the lungs. Complicated CWP has nodules ≥1 cm in diameter generally confined to the upper half of the lungs.
